DataElement.preferredName: Acute Myeloid Leukemia Prior Preparative Regimen Imatinib Mesylate Pharmacotherapy Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues.  The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia 3) Therapy-related AML 4) AML not otherwise categorized.  The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML has been recently reduced from 30% (French-American-British [FAB] classification) to 20% (WHO classification).  (WHO, 2001)._ Earlier in time or order._The chemotherapy and/or radiation given to bone marrow transplant patients prior to transplant to kill diseased cells and/or make space for healthy new marrow and/or suppress the immune system so graft rejection does not occur._The mesylate salt of imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibtor with antiproliferative activity.  Imatinib binds to an intracellular pocket located within the tyrosine kinase (TK), thereby inhibiting ATP binding, preventing phosphorylation and the subsequent activation of growth receptors and their downstream signal transduction pathways.  This agent inhibits the TK encoded by the bcr-abl oncogene as well as receptor TKs encoded by the c-kit and platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR) oncogenes. Inhibition of the bcr-abl TK results in decreased proliferation and enhanced apoptosis in malignant cells of Philadelphia-positive (Ph+) hematological malignancies such as CMAL and ALL; effects on c-kit TK activity inhibits mast-cell and cellular proliferation in those diseases overexpressing c-kit, such as mastocytosis and GIST. Imantinib also inhibits cellular proliferation in diseases involving dysregulated PDGFR signaling pathways._Treatment of disease through the use of drugs._Indicator of Yes, No, Unknown, Not Done, or Not Applicable to a question.[manually curated]

Imantinib also inhibits cellular proliferation in diseases involving dysregulated PDGFR signaling pathways._Treatment of disease through the use of drugs.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues.  The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia 3) Therapy-related AML 4) AML not otherwise categorized.  The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML has been recently reduced from 30% (French-American-British [FAB] classification) to 20% (WHO classification).  (WHO, 2001) -- 2003

Concepts.definition: A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues. The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities; 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia; 3) Therapy-related AML; 4) AML not otherwise specified. The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML is 20% (WHO classification).

Property.preferredName: Prior Preparative Regimen Imatinib Mesylate Pharmacotherapy
Property.preferredDefinition:
Earlier in time or order.:The chemotherapy and/or radiation given to bone marrow transplant patients prior to transplant to kill
diseased cells and/or make space for healthy new marrow and/or suppress the immune system so graft rejection does not
occur.:The mesylate salt of an antineoplastic agent that inhibits the Bcr-Abl fusion protein tyrosine kinase, an abnormal enzyme produced by chronic myeloid leukemia cells that contain the Philadelphia chromosome.  Imatinib also inhibits the receptor tyrosine kinases for platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and stem cell factor (SCF)/c-kit; the SCF/c-kit receptor tyrosine kinase is activated in gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST).  This agent inhibits proliferation and induces apoptosis in cells that overexpress these oncoproteins. It is also known as Gleevec.:Treatment of disease through the use of drugs.

Concepts.definition: The chemotherapy or radiation given prior to blood, marrow, cord blood transplant, or cell infusion to kill diseased cells and make space for the healthy new graft and/or suppress the immune system so rejection does not occur.

The mesylate salt of imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor with antineoplastic activity. Imatinib binds to an intracellular pocket located within tyrosine kinases (TK), thereby inhibiting ATP binding and preventing phosphorylation and the subsequent activation of growth receptors and their downstream signal transduction pathways. This agent inhibits TK encoded by the bcr-abl oncogene as well as receptor TKs encoded by the c-kit and platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR) oncogenes. Inhibition of the bcr-abl TK results in decreased proliferation and enhanced apoptosis in malignant cells of Philadelphia-positive (Ph+) hematological malignancies such as CML and ALL; effects on c-kit TK activity inhibit mast-cell and cellular proliferation in those diseases overexpressing c-kit, such as mastocytosis and gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST).
Treatment of disease through the use of drugs.
